message.content:
Implement the following plan:

# Redesign: "The Lens" — Morphing Spotlight Onboarding Tour

## Context

The current `tour-overlay.tsx` is a generic modal slideshow — a centered card with fade animations. It defines `target` selectors (`data-tour="pipeline"`, etc.) but **never uses them**. The overlay doesn't actually highlight any UI elements; it's just 5 identical centered modals with different text. For a platform called Apollo (god of knowledge, space exploration), the onboarding should feel like a lens bringing the workspace into focus.

**Research sources**: [Awwwards onboarding inspiration](https://www.awwwards.com/inspiration/onboarding), [Figma's animated onboarding](https://goodux.appcues.com/blog/figmas-animated-onboarding-flow), [Appcues product tour UI patterns](https://www.appcues.com/blog/product-tours-ui-patterns), [NNGroup on onboarding tutorials](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/onboarding-tutorials/), [Motion (Framer Motion) docs](https://motion.dev/docs/react-animation), [Aceternity spotlight components](https://www.aceternity.com/components), [UX Collective onboarding patterns](https://uxdesign.cc/menu-of-ux-onboarding-patterns-and-when-to-use-them-3df2e3880fd1)

---

## Concept: Morphing Spotlight with Glass Cards

An SVG mask creates a soft-edged cutout that **morphs fluidly between target elements** using spring physics. A frosted glass tooltip floats near each target. The spotlight has a breathing sage-green glow ring matching Apollo's cursor-tracking glow DNA.

### What Makes It Special

| Technique | Description |
|-----------|-------------|
| **SVG mask morph** | The spotlight GLIDES between targets — no cut, no fade. Spring physics make it feel alive |
| **Feathered edge** | SVG `feGaussianBlur` on the mask cutout creates a soft, cinematic vignette |
| **Breathing glow** | Sage-green ring pulses gently around the spotlight (3s cycle, opacity 0.08→0.20) |
| **Glass tooltip** | Frosted card (`backdrop-blur-[20px] bg-white/85`) positioned smartly near target |
| **Aperture open/close** | Entry: spotlight scales from zero. Exit: expands to reveal everything |
| **Pipeline-style dots** | Progress uses 3-tier dot hierarchy matching the pipeline timeline component |
| **Keyboard nav** | ArrowRight/Enter = next, ArrowLeft = back, Escape = dismiss |

---

## Tour Steps (5 steps)

| # | Target | Card Position | Title | Copy |
|---|--------|---------------|-------|------|
| 0 | None (welcome) | Center | Welcome to Apollo | "Let's take a quick look around your thesis workspace." |
| 1 | `[data-tour='pipeline']` | Below | The Pipeline | "Your thesis follows 12 phases. Complete each milestone to progress." |
| 2 | `[data-tour='compile']` | Below | Generate & Approve | "AI generates each chapter. You review, refine, and approve before advancing." |
| 3 | `[data-tour='editor']` | Right | The Editor | "Full LaTeX editing power. The AI's output is your starting point --- make it yours." |
| 4 | None (finish) | Center | You're Ready | "That's all you need. Let's build something remarkable." |

---

## Technical Architecture

### Layer Stack (z-index)

```
z-[102]  Glass Tooltip Card (DOM div)       ← Positioned near cutout
z-[101]  Glow Ring (DOM div, CSS @keyframes) ← Sage pulse around cutout
z-[100]  SVG Mask Overlay (full viewport)    ← Dark scrim + feathered cutout
         Workspace (existing UI)             ← data-tour targets
```

### Core: SVG Mask Spotlight

```tsx
<svg className="pointer-events-none fixed inset-0 z-[100]" style={{ width: "100vw", height: "100vh" }}>
  <defs>
    <filter id="spotlight-feather">
      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="10" />
    </filter>
    <mask id="spotlight-mask">
      <rect width="100%" height="100%" fill="white" />
      <motion.rect
        animate={{ x, y, width, height }}
        transition={{ type: "spring", stiffness: 170, damping: 26 }}
        rx="16" fill="black"
        filter="url(#spotlight-feather)"
      />
    </mask>
  </defs>
  <rect width="100%" height="100%" fill="rgba(0,0,0,0.55)" mask="url(#spotlight-mask)" />
</svg>
```

`motion.rect` (Framer Motion for SVG) animates the cutout position/size with spring physics.

### Glow Ring (breathing sage pulse)

DOM div with animated `box-shadow`, positioned to match the spotlight cutout:

```css
/* globals.css */
@keyframes tour-breathe {
  0%, 100% { box-shadow: 0 0 0 2px rgba(139,157,119,0.08), 0 0 20px 4px rgba(139,157,119,0.05); }
  50%      { box-shadow: 0 0 0 2px rgba(139,157,119,0.22), 0 0 40px 12px rgba(139,157,119,0.10); }
}
```

### Glass Tooltip Card

- `bg-white/85 backdrop-blur-[20px] border border-white/40 rounded-2xl shadow-xl`
- Progress dots: 3-tier sizing (current=`h-2 w-2 bg-[#2F2F2F]`, done=`h-1.5 w-1.5 bg-[#8B9D77]`, future=`h-1.5 w-1.5 bg-[#D1D1D1]`)
- Typography: `font-serif text-base font-semibold text-[#2F2F2F]` title, `text-[13px] text-[#6B6B6B]` body
- Nav: ghost "Skip tour" left, solid "Next"/"Get Started" right

### Smart Card Positioning

```typescript
function computeCardPosition(
  targetRect: DOMRect | null,
  preference: "bottom" | "top" | "right" | "left" | "center"
): { x: number; y: number }
  // 1. Try preferred direction with 16px gap from target
  // 2. Clamp to viewport with 20px edge padding
  // 3. For "center" (welcome/finish): viewport center
```

### Animation Timeline

| Event | Animation |
|-------|-----------|
| Tour opens | Overlay: opacity 0→1 (400ms). Welcome card: scale 0.92→1 + fade (spring) |
| Step → Step | SVG rect + glow ring morph to new target (~500ms spring). Card: exit up 8px (200ms), enter down 12px (300ms, 150ms delay) |
| Tour closes | Spotlight rect scales to viewport size (400ms spring), then overlay fades out (300ms) |

### Responsive

- **Desktop (≥768px)**: Full spotlight tour with SVG mask
- **Mobile (<768px)**: Glass cards only (centered, no spotlight) — the workspace layout differs on mobile so spotlighting specific elements doesn't work well

### Keyboard

`useEffect` with `keydown` listener: `ArrowRight`/`Enter` → next, `ArrowLeft` → back, `Escape` → dismiss.

### Window Resize

`useEffect` with `resize` + `ResizeObserver` on active target element → recalculate spotlight rect on layout changes.

---

## Files to Modify

| # | File | Change |
|---|------|--------|
| 1 | `apps/web/components/onboarding/tour-overlay.tsx` | **REWRITE** — morphing spotlight with SVG mask, glass cards, glow ring, keyboard nav, responsive fallback |
| 2 | `apps/web/app/globals.css` | **ADD** — `@keyframes tour-breathe` animation |

**No new files. No new dependencies.** Uses existing `motion/react` + SVG + Tailwind.

`project-workspace.tsx` needs **no changes** — the `data-tour` attributes and `<TourOverlay />` integration are already in place.

---

## Verification

1. `pnpm --filter apollo-web exec tsc --noEmit` — 0 errors
2. Clear localStorage: `localStorage.removeItem("apollo_onboarding_complete")` → refresh → tour appears
3. Desktop: spotlight morphs between all targets, glass card positions correctly
4. Keyboard: arrows navigate, escape dismisses
5. Mobile (<768px): glass cards centered, no spotlight
6. Dismiss → refresh → tour does NOT reappear
7. Window resize during tour → spotlight repositions


If you need specific details from before exiting plan mode (like exact code snippets, error messages, or content you generated), read the full transcript at: /Users/devs/.REDACTED.jsonl

## Context

For a platform called Apollo (god of knowledge, space exploration), the onboarding should feel like a lens bringing the workspace into focus.

**Research sources**: [Awwwards onboarding inspiration](https://www.awwwards.com/inspiration/onboarding), [Figma's animated onboarding](https://goodux.appcues.com/blog/figmas-animated-onboarding-flow), [Appcues product tour UI patterns](https://www.appcues.com/blog/product-tours-ui-patterns), [NNGroup on onboarding tutorials](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/onboarding-tutorials/), [Motion (Framer Motion) docs](https://motion.dev/docs/react-animation), [Aceternity spotlight components](https://www.aceternity.com/components), [UX Collective onboarding patterns](https://uxdesign.cc/menu-of-ux-onboarding-patterns-and-when-to-use-them-3df2e3880fd1)

### Glow Ring (breathing sage pulse)

| # | File | Change |

| 1 | `apps/web/components/onboarding/tour-overlay.tsx` | **REWRITE** — morphing spotlight with SVG mask, glass cards, glow ring, keyboard nav, responsive fallback |

`project-workspace.tsx` needs **no changes** — the `data-tour` attributes and `<TourOverlay />` integration are already in place.

message.content:
Suggested Upgrades & Flourishes (The "Award" Polish)
While the plan is already excellent, here are a few upgrades to push it into true "Awwwards" territory:

1. Parallax Tooltip Drift
Instead of the tooltip card remaining perfectly static while the user reads, add a microscopic, continuous multi-directional drift using framer-motion.

Implementation: Wrap the tooltip card in a <motion.div> that slowly translates 2-3px on X/Y over a 10-second repeating, reverse animation loop. It makes the UI feel suspended in liquid rather than bolted to the screen.
2. Audio Design (Micro-Interactions)
Premium experiences engage more than just the eyes.

Implementation: Add a very soft, satisfying, muffled "click" or "whoosh" audio file that plays exactly as the spring animation resolves on a new target. It dramatically increases the tactile feel of the software. (Think of the sound design in products like Linear or Arc Browser).
3. The "Lens Flare" Transition
When jumping from one target to another that is physically far away (e.g., from the bottom-left Sidebar to the top-right Compile button), the spotlight has to travel a long distance.

Implementation: During long morphs, temporarily increase the width and height of the SVG rect mask by ~20% during the middle of the spring transit, then settle back to the exact target size. This creates an "aperture breathing" effect, making the transition feel dynamic rather than just a linear slide.
4. Interactive Target Elements
Currently, the spotlight highlights an element, but the user clicks "Next" on the tooltip.

Implementation: Allow the user to actually click through the spotlight cutout to interact with the target element (e.g., actually clicking the "Compile" button inside the spotlight to advance the tour). You can achieve this using pointer-events: none on the overlay, but pointer-events: auto on the tooltip card.
 Doable?

content.thinking:
The user wants me to implement the morphing spotlight onboarding tour ("The Lens") as described in the plan, plus the suggested upgrades. Let me start by reading the current files I need to modify.

Let me read the current tour-overlay.tsx and globals.css to understand what exists, then implement the rewrite.

The upgrades requested:
1. Parallax tooltip drift - subtle motion on tooltip
2. Audio design - skip this one, it requires audio files
3. Lens flare transition - aperture breathing during long morphs
4. Interactive target elements - pointer-events passthrough on spotlight

Let me start by reading the files.

content.text: Yes, all four upgrades are doable. Let me read the current files first.

content.text:
Both phases complete. Here's a summary of everything implemented:

## Phase 1 — Core Morphing Spotlight Tour

- **SVG mask spotlight** with `feGaussianBlur` feathered edges that glides between `data-tour` targets via spring physics (`motion.rect`)
- **Breathing sage glow ring** (`@keyframes tour-breathe` in globals.css) — 3s pulsing `box-shadow` at `#8B9D77`
- **Glass tooltip card** — `bg-white/85 backdrop-blur-[20px]`, smart positioning (bottom/top/right/left/centre) with viewport clamping
- **3-tier progress dots** matching pipeline timeline (current=dark `h-2`, done=sage `h-1.5`, future=grey `h-1.5`)
- **Aperture open/close** — entry fades in, exit expands spotlight to full viewport then fades
- **Keyboard nav** — ArrowRight/Enter, ArrowLeft, Escape
- **Responsive** — desktop gets SVG spotlight, mobile (<768px) gets centred glass cards only
- **Resize + ResizeObserver** — spotlight repositions on layout changes

## Phase 2 — Award Polish

1. **Parallax tooltip drift** — `motion.div` wrapper with 2px multi-axis keyframe loop (10s infinite), gives the card a "floating in liquid" feel
2. **Audio whoosh** — Web Audio API synthesised 200ms sine sweep (600Hz→200Hz, gain 0.04) on step transitions. No external audio files needed. Fails silently if audio unavailable
3. **Lens flare** — When morph distance > 300px, an inflated (+20%) midpoint spotlight is set first, then the final target 180ms later. The spring redirects mid-flight creating a breathing aperture effect
4. **Interactive targets** — `pointer-events: none` on overlay, `pointer-events: auto` on tooltip card. Click listener on the active `data-tour` element advances to the next step

**Files changed**: `tour-overlay.tsx` (rewritten), `globals.css` (+5 lines). Zero new files, zero new dependencies, zero TypeScript errors.

content.thinking: The user wants me to audit the two changed files. Let me re-read both files carefully and look for bugs, issues, or inconsistencies.

Let me carefully audit both files for bugs, issues, and potential problems.

## tour-overlay.tsx Audit

### Bug 1: SSR crash — `centreSpotlight()` calls `window.innerWidth` at module level
Line 200: `const [spotlight, setSpotlight] = useState(centreSpotlight);`
Line 203: `const prevSpotlightRef = useRef(centreSpotlight());`

Wait, `useState(centreSpotlight)` — this passes the function as an initializer, which means React will call it lazily. But it's still called during the first render, which happens on the server in SSR. 

The `centreSpotlight` function directly accesses `window.innerWidth` and `window.innerHeight` to calculate the center coordinates, but `window` doesn't exist in a server environment. Even though the component is marked with `"use client"`, Next.js still performs initial server-side rendering, so this will crash before the component ever reaches the browser.

The issue is that both `useState(centreSpotlight)` and `useRef(centreSpotlight())` invoke this function during render, which happens on the server. I need to either use a safe fallback value like `{ x: 0, y: 0, width: 2, height: 2 }` and then update it in a `useEffect` once the component mounts, or guard the function with a `typeof window !== 'undefined'` check.

There are also two cleanup issues with timers. The lens flare effect sets a timeout to update the spotlight after 180ms, but if the component unmounts or the step changes before that fires, the callback will set stale state. Similarly, the dismiss timeout isn't being cleared properly, which could cause the same problem.

The bigger performance issue is that both the interactive target and keyboard event listeners are set up in `useEffect` calls without dependency arrays, so they're being added and removed on every single render. The handlers themselves (`handleNext`, `handlePrev`, `handleDismiss`) are recreated each render too since they're not wrapped in `useCallback`, so they're always closing over stale values. I should wrap these handlers in `useCallback` and add proper dependencies to the effects. The `recalculate` function is wrapped in `useCallback` with `currentStep` and `isDesktop` as dependencies, so it gets recreated when either changes — which then triggers the effect that calls it. The pattern works correctly since it checks `isInitialMount.current` to decide whether to pass the `flare` parameter, but there's a timing issue when `isDesktop` changes across the responsive breakpoint.

When the window resizes and crosses the 768px threshold, `isDesktop` flips, `recalculate` gets a new reference, the effect fires, and since `isInitialMount` is already false, it calls `recalculate(true)` — triggering the audio and lens flare unintentionally on a desktop/mobile transition.

For the glow ring, I'm looking at how it's using `x` and `y` as animate properties on a `motion.div`. Since Framer Motion treats these as transform-based properties (translateX/translateY) and the div is positioned fixed with pointer-events disabled, this should work correctly.

Examining the SVG mask's `motion.rect` — it also animates `x`, `y`, `width`, and `height`, but for SVG elements these are actual attributes rather than transforms, which Framer Motion handles appropriately.

There's also an issue with AudioContext creation on every step change — a new context gets instantiated each time, which is wasteful since browsers limit these instances. Reusing a single context would be more efficient.

The click listener setup uses `{ once: true }` for auto-removal, but the cleanup function also calls `removeEventListener`, creating redundancy — though it's harmless since the second removal is a no-op if the listener already fired.

There's a potential race condition where clicking the interactive target and then quickly clicking "Next" could advance two steps, though the `once: true` flag provides some protection against this.

The card positioning mixes CSS `left`/`top` for the fixed element with Framer Motion's transform-based `y` animation, which works but creates an inconsistency in how positioning is handled.

On mobile specifically, there's a real bug: the card has an explicit `transform: "translate(-50%, -50%)"` in the style for centering, but Framer Motion's animation system will override this transform entirely rather than composing with it, breaking the mobile centering.

There's also a ref timing issue with the keyed motion.div — when the step changes, the ref gets reassigned to the new element, but the height calculation in `recalculate` might be reading from the wrong card during the transition. change, which might be during the exit animation when the old card is still in the DOM but the ref might have been detached.

Actually in React, when a keyed element unmounts, the ref is set to null. When the new element mounts, the ref is set to the new element. With `mode="wait"`, the old exits first, THEN the new enters. So between exit and enter, `cardRef.current` would be null, and `cardRef.current?.offsetHeight ?? 180` falls back to 180. This might cause an initial incorrect card position for a frame or two, but it's barely noticeable. Minor issue.

I've identified several bugs across different severity levels. The critical ones are the SSR crash from using `window` directly in initial state and refs, and the mobile card centering being overridden by Framer Motion's y animation. There are medium-priority issues like uncleared timeouts that could fire after unmount, the desktop/mobile transition triggering unnecessary flare and audio, and effects missing dependency arrays. The minor issues include the glow ring lacking explicit positioning and creating a new AudioContext per step.

content.text:
Found several bugs, two critical. Here's the full audit:

### Critical

| # | Line(s) | Bug | Impact |
|---|---------|-----|--------|
| **C1** | 86-90, 200, 203 | **SSR crash** — `centreSpotlight()` accesses `window.innerWidth` directly. `useState(centreSpotlight)` (lazy init) and `useRef(centreSpotlight())` (immediate) both execute during server render where `window` is undefined. Next.js SSR will throw `ReferenceError: window is not defined`. | App crashes on page load |
| **C2** | 443-444, 457 | **Mobile card not centred** — Card uses `style={{ transform: "translate(-50%, -50%)" }}` for mobile centering, but Framer Motion's `animate={{ y: 0 }}` / `initial={{ y: 12 }}` **takes over** the `transform` property entirely. FM replaces the CSS transform with `translateY(0px)`, so the card renders at 50%/50% from its **top-left corner**, not centred. | Card misaligned on all mobile viewports |

### Medium

| # | Line(s) | Bug | Impact |
|---|---------|-----|--------|
| **M1** | 240 | **Uncleared lens flare timeout** — `setTimeout(() => setSpotlight(target), 180)` is never stored/cleared. If user clicks Next twice within 180ms, the first timeout fires and sets a stale spotlight rect. | Spotlight flickers to wrong position on fast clicking |
| **M2** | 347-351 | **Uncleared dismiss timeout** — 500ms `setTimeout` in `handleDismiss` not cleared on unmount. If parent unmounts `TourOverlay` during exit animation, React logs "setState on unmounted component". | Console warning, potential stale state |
| **M3** | 264-269 | **Desktop/mobile transition triggers flare + audio** — When `isDesktop` changes (resize crosses 768px), `recalculate` gets a new reference → effect fires with `flare = true` → plays whoosh and potentially triggers lens flare. Unintended. | Random whoosh sound on window resize |
| **M4** | 296-305, 308-324 | **Effects without dependency arrays** — Both keyboard and interactive-target `useEffect` calls have no deps array, re-running on **every render**. Adds/removes event listeners every render cycle. | Performance waste, potential double-fire in StrictMode |

### Minor

| # | Line(s) | Bug | Impact |
|---|---------|-----|--------|
| **m1** | 420-434 | **Glow ring missing `top: 0; left: 0`** — `position: fixed` div relies on implicit (0,0) positioning. Without explicit offsets, the starting position depends on document flow. | Could misalign in edge cases |
| **m2** | 122-140 | **New AudioContext per step** — Creates and closes a fresh `AudioContext` on every step transition. Chrome limits to 6 concurrent contexts. | Works but wasteful; could hit limit with rapid clicking |

---

Fixing all of them now:

content.thinking:
The issue is that `useCallback` requires explicit deps, but the handlers reference functions through refs. Let me check the actual lines:

Line 214 would be around the handler refs being called without arguments. Let me look at this more carefully.

Actually, the issue is that `handleNextRef.current?.()` is fine, but the problem is with the `useCallback` wrapping `handleNext`, `handlePrev`, `handleDismiss`. They call `handleDismissRef.current?.()` which is `(() => void) | undefined`, but the problem might be that the ref type doesn't match.

Wait, let me look at the actual line numbers. The error says "Expected 1 arguments, but got 0" at lines 214, 215, 314, 315, 316.


Let me trace through the ref types more carefully—`useRef<() => void>()` initializes with `undefined`, so the current value is `(() => void) | undefined`, and the optional chaining with `?.()` should handle that correctly. The error might be coming from somewhere else in how the refs are being invoked.

Actually, I think I found it—the `useCallback` for `handleNext` is calling `handleDismissRef.current?.()`, but `handleDismissRef` hasn't been initialized yet at that point in the code, which could be causing the TypeScript error about argument count. Looking at the `handleNext` callback, I'm wondering if the issue is with how `useRef` is initialized without an argument—in newer React type definitions, that might require the type to account for `undefined` as a possible value. Let me reconsider the React 19 type overloads for `useRef`. The no-argument version should return `MutableRefObject<T | undefined>`, so `useRef<() => void>()` would give me `MutableRefObject<(() => void) | undefined>`, which should work fine.

Actually, I think the issue might be with the `useCallback` hooks instead. Both `handleNext` and `handleDismiss` are defined with `useCallback`, and they reference each other through refs, but `handleDismiss` also includes `exiting` in its dependency array. Let me look at the actual error more carefully to understand what's really happening here. Looking at the actual code structure around those lines, I see the refs are declared with `useRef<() => void>()` but then I'm calling `handleDismissRef.current?.()` — the issue is that `useRef` needs an initial value argument, so I should be using `useRef<() => void>(undefined)` or just `useRef(null)` to properly initialize them. I'm wondering if the issue is with how `useRef` is being typed without an initial value—TypeScript might be inferring the ref type differently than expected, causing the optional chaining call to fail type checking even though `?.()` should work on a `(() => void) | undefined` type. I see the pattern now—all five `useRef` calls are missing initial values, which is why TypeScript is complaining that they need an argument. I need to provide `undefined` or appropriate default values for each ref, like `useRef<() => void>(undefined)` for the handler refs and `useRef<ReturnType<typeof setTimeout>>(undefined)` for the timeout refs.

content.text: The 5 `useRef` calls without initial values need explicit `undefined`. Let me fix.
Exactly the 5 lines from the TS errors. React 19 types require an explicit initial value for `useRef<T>()`.

content.text:
Zero errors. All 8 bugs fixed:

| Fix | What changed |
|-----|-------------|
| **C1** SSR crash | `useState(DEFAULT_SPOTLIGHT)` + `useRef(DEFAULT_SPOTLIGHT)` — static object, no `window` access |
| **C2** Mobile centering | Replaced `transform: translate(-50%, -50%)` with `marginLeft`/`marginTop` negative offsets (FM doesn't clobber margins) |
| **M1** Stale flare timeout | Stored in `flareTimeoutRef`, cleared on every `recalculate()` call + unmount |
| **M2** Stale dismiss timeout | Stored in `dismissTimeoutRef`, cleared on unmount |
| **M3** Resize triggers flare | Added `prevIsDesktopRef` — desktop toggle detected and suppresses flare |
| **M4** No-deps effects | Keyboard + interactive target effects now have proper dependency arrays, using stable handler refs |
| **m1** Glow ring positioning | Added explicit `top: 0, left: 0` to style |
| **m2** AudioContext per step | Shared `sharedAudioCtx` module-level singleton, reused across steps |

git add apps/web/components/onboarding/tour-overlay.tsx apps/web/app/globals.css && git commit -m "$(cat <<'EOF'
Redesign onboarding tour: morphing SVG spotlight with glass cards

Replace generic centered-modal slideshow with "The Lens" — a cinematic
onboarding experience using SVG mask cutouts that morph between
data-tour targets with spring physics.

Core: feathered-edge SVG spotlight, breathing sage glow ring, frosted
glass tooltip cards with smart positioning, 3-tier pipeline-style
progress dots, aperture open/close animations, keyboard nav, responsive
mobile fallback (glass cards only, no spotlight).

Polish: parallax tooltip drift, Web Audio synthesised whoosh on
transitions, lens flare aperture breathing on long morphs, interactive
click-through on spotlight targets.

Co-Authored-By: Claude Opus 4.6 <noreply@anthropic.com>
EOF
)"
